intro: Ceratophorus wightii, commonly known as the Wight's spurge, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae, which includes many species with distinctive floral structures. The plant typically grows as an annual herb, characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers. It is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of environmental conditions. Its latex-containing stems and leaves are part of its adaptive features for survival in its native habitat.
